Fiction
HARRY POTTER AND THE SORCERER'S STONE, by J. K. Rowling. (Scholastic, $5.99.) A British boy attends a school for witchcraft.
THE GREEN MILE, by Stephen King. (Pocket, $7.99.) A six-part thriller set on death row.
SOUTHERN CROSS, by Patricia Cornwell. (Berkley, $7.99.) A former police chief finds herself summoned to Richmond, Va., to clean up scandalous conditions.
SEIZE THE NIGHT, by Dean Koontz. (Bantam, $7.99.) Christopher Snow seeks to discover why children in his hometown keep disappearing.
JEWELS OF THE SUN, by Nora Roberts. (Jove, $7.50.) A woman finds romance in Ireland.
VINEGAR HILL, by A. Manette Ansay. (Avon, $13.) A woman moves with her children and unemployed husband to live with his loveless family.
A MAP OF THE WORLD, by Jane Hamilton. (Anchor, $12.95.) When a dairy farmer's wife makes a mistake one morning, her life falls apart.
TOM CLANCY'S POWER PLAYS: Shadow Watch, created by Tom Clancy and Martin Greenberg. (Berkley, $7.99.) Terrorists target a space station project in 2001.
MIRROR IMAGE, by Danielle Steel. (Dell, $7.99.) Identical twin sisters experience dissimilar lives.
POKEMON: Nos. 1-5, adapted by Tracey West. (Scholastic, $4.50 each.) Stories about the characters currently popular with children.
WELCOME TO THE WORLD, BABY GIRL! by Fannie Flagg. (Ballantine, $7.50.) The pleasures and problems of a rising star in television news.
INTO THE GARDEN, by V. C. Andrews. (Pocket, $7.99.) Four troubled teenage girls, subjects of the ''Wildflowers'' series, stage a revealing reunion.
*POKEMON: Mewtwo Strikes Back and Pikachu's Vacation, adapted by Tracey West. (Scholastic, $4.99 and $4.50.) Illustrated adaptations of ''Pokemon'' stories.
*THE POISONWOOD BIBLE, by Barbara Kingsolver. (HarperPerennial, $14.) Five female characters narrate a novel set in the Belgian Congo during that country's fight for independence.
*A SUDDEN CHANGE OF HEART, by Barbara Taylor Bradford. (Dell, $7.99.) When tragedy strikes, a woman turns to her best friend, an art dealer, for help.

Nonfiction
ANGELA'S ASHES, by Frank McCourt. (Touchstone/S&S, $14 and $7.99.) An Irish-American writer recalls his childhood in Limerick.
OUR DUMB CENTURY, edited by Scott Dikkers. (Three Rivers, $15.) Newspaper headlines making fun of the great events of the past century.
A WALK IN THE WOODS, by Bill Bryson. (Broadway, $13.) A journalist finds beauty and humor while hiking the Appalachian Trail.
*THE SEAT OF THE SOUL, by Gary Zukav. (Fireside/S&S, $12.) How daily activities can be enhanced by feelings of meaning and purpose. (+)
THE PERFECT STORM, by Sebastian Junger. (HarperPerennial, $14; HarperPaperbacks, $6.99.) The story of the northeaster of 1991, focusing on a single crew of fishermen.
BLIND MAN'S BLUFF, by Sherry Sontag and Christopher Drew with Annette Lawrence Drew. (HarperPaperbacks, $7.99.) American espionage by submarine, from the cold war to the present.
THE PROFESSOR AND THE MADMAN, by Simon Winchester. (HarperPerennial, $13.) How a murderer helped compile the O.E.D.
GUNS, GERMS, AND STEEl, by Jared Diamond. (Norton, $14.95.) A physiologist attributes Western dominance to geography. (+)
A CHILD CALLED ''IT,'' by Dave Pelzer. (Health Communications, $9.95.) The autobiography of a man who survived his mother's abuse. (+)
THE LOST BOY, by Dave Pelzer. (Health Communications, $10.95.) The author of ''A Child Called 'It' ''recalls his life in foster homes. (+)
*INTO THIN AIR, by Jon Krakauer. (Anchor, $7.99.) Ascending Mount Everest in 1996, the deadliest season in history.
THE MILLIONAIRE NEXT DOOR, by Thomas J. Stanley and William D. Danko. (Pocket, $14.) An analysis of the lives of wealthy Americans. (+)
ENDURANCE, by Alfred Lansing. (Carroll & Graf, $12.95.) Ernest Shackleton's 1914 Antarctic expedition.
OPHELIA SPEAKS, by Sara Shandler. (HarperPerennial, $12.95.) Adolescent girls discuss their feelings about themselves and about life. (+)
*UNDER THE TUSCAN SUN, by Frances Mayes. (Broadway, $13.) A celebration of life in the Italian countryside.

Rankings reflect sales, for the week ending Dec. 18, at almost 4,000 bookstores plus wholesalers serving 60,000 other retailers, statistically weighted to represent all such outlets. An asterisk (*) indicates that a book's sales are barely distinguishable from those of the book above. A dagger (+)indicates that some stores received bulk orders. Expanded rankings are available from The New York Times on the Web: www.nytimes.com/books.
